problem:
Express the value of the following as a common fraction:
$\left(1-\frac12\right)\cdot\left(1-\frac13\right)\cdot\left(1-\frac14\right) \dotsm \left(1-\frac1{n+1}\right) \dotsm \left(1-\frac1{100}\right)$
solution: Simplifying each term in the product, we have \[\left( \frac{1}{2} \right) \left( \frac{2}{3} \right) \left( \frac{3}{4} \right) \dotsm \left( \frac{98}{99} \right) \left( \frac{99}{100} \right) . \]The denominator of each fraction cancels with the numerator of the next fraction, so the product is $\boxed{\frac{1}{100}}.$
model_solution:
To express the given expression as a common fraction, we will start by simplifying each factor:

$\left(1-\frac12\right) = \left(\frac{1}{1}-\frac{1}{2}\right) = \frac{1}{2}$ 

So, the expression becomes:
$\frac{1}{2} \cdot \left(1-\frac13\right) \cdot \left(1-\frac14\right) \dotsm \left(1-\frac1{100}\right)$
$\left(1-\frac13\right) = \left(\frac{1}{1}-\frac{1}{3}\right) = \frac{2}{3}$

The expression becomes:
$\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \left(1-\frac14\right) \dotsm \left(1-\frac1{100}\right)$
$\left(1-\frac14\right) = \left(\frac{1}{1}-\frac{1}{4}\right) = \frac{3}{4}$

The expression becomes:
$\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \left(1-\frac15\right) \dotsm \left(1-\frac1{100}\right)$
Continuing the pattern:
$\left(1-\frac15\right) = \left(\frac{1}{1}-\frac{1}{5}\right) = \frac{4}{5}$

The expression becomes:
$\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{4}{5} \cdot \left(1-\frac16\right) \dotsm \left(1-\frac1{100}\right)$
$\left(1-\frac16\right) = \left(\frac{1}{1}-\frac{1}{6}\right) = \frac{5}{6}$

The expression becomes:
$\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{4}{5} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \left(1-\frac17\right) \dotsm \left(1-\frac1{100}\right)$
Continuing the pattern:
$\left(1-\frac17\right) = \left(\frac{1}{1}-\frac{1}{7}\right) = \frac{6}{7}$

The expression becomes:
$\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{4}{5} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{6}{7} \cdot \left(1-\frac18\right) \dotsm \left(1-\frac1{100}\right)$
$\left(1-\frac18\right) = \left(\frac{1}{1}-\frac{1}{8}\right) = \frac{7}{8}$

The expression becomes:
$\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{4}{5} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{6}{7} \cdot \frac{7}{8} \dotsm \left(1-\frac1{100}\right)$
Continuing the pattern:
$\left(1-\frac1{100}\right) = \left(\frac{1}{1}-\frac{1}{100}\right) = \frac{99}{100}$

The expression becomes:
$\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{4}{5} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{6}{7} \cdot \frac{7}{8} \cdot \frac{8}{9} \cdot \frac{9}{10} \cdot \frac{10}{11} \cdot \frac{11}{12} \cdot \frac{12}{13} \cdot \frac{13}{14} \cdot \frac{14}{15} \cdot \frac{15}{16} \cdot \frac{16}{17} \cdot \frac{17}{18} \cdot \frac{18}{19} \cdot \frac{19}{20} \cdot \frac{20}{21} \cdot \frac{21}{22} \cdot \frac{22}{23} \cdot \frac{
$\frac{23}{24} \cdot \left(1-\frac1{25}\right) = \frac{23}{24} \cdot \left(\frac{1}{1}-\frac{1}{25}\right) = \frac{23}{24} \cdot \frac{24}{25}$

The expression becomes:
$\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{4}{5} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{6}{7} \cdot \frac{7}{8} \cdot \frac{8}{9} \cdot \frac{9}{10} \cdot \frac{10}{11} \cdot \frac{11}{12} \cdot \frac{12}{13} \cdot \frac{13}{14} \cdot \frac{14}{15} \cdot \frac{15}{16} \cdot \frac{16}{17} \cdot \frac{17}{18} \cdot \frac{18}{19} \cdot \frac{19}{20} \cdot \frac{20}{21} \
Continuing the pattern:
$\left(1-\frac1{25}\right) = \left(\frac{1}{1}-\frac{1}{25}\right) = \frac{24}{25}$

The expression becomes:
$\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{4}{5} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{6}{7} \cdot \frac{7}{8} \cdot \frac{8}{9} \cdot \frac{9}{10} \cdot \frac{10}{11} \cdot \frac{11}{12} \cdot \frac{12}{13} \cdot \frac{13}{14} \cdot \frac{14}{15} \cdot \frac{15}{16} \cdot \frac{16}{17} \cdot \frac{17}{18} \cdot \frac{18}{19} \cdot \frac{19}{20} \cdot \frac{20}{21} \cdot \frac{21}{22} \cdot \frac{22}{23} \cdot \frac{
